Canonical maintains two discrete versions of Unity which are almost indistinguishable from a visual standpoint but very different on the technical level.
Canonical maintains two discrete versions of Unity which are almost indistinguishable from a visual standpoint but very different on the technical level.
â
Unity is written as a plugin for Compiz<ref name="CompizPlugin" /> and is written in the programming languages C++ and [[Vala_(programming_language)|Vala]] and is utilizing an uncommon OpenGL toolkit called Nux. Being a plugin for Compiz gives Unity GPU-accelerated performance on compatible systems.<br>
+
Unity is written as a plugin for Compiz<ref name="CompizPlugin" /> and is written in the programming languages C++ and [[Vala_(programming_language)|Vala]] and is utilizing an uncommon [[OpenGL]] toolkit called Nux. Being a plugin for Compiz gives Unity GPU-accelerated performance on compatible systems.<br>
Unity 2D is a set of individual applications.<ref name="2D-Components">[[:File:Unity-2D Natty.png]]</ref> They are written in the GUI building language QML from the widespread Qt framework.<ref name="2D-QML" /> By default Unity 2D uses the non-compositing [[Metacity]] window manager<ref name="2D-Components" /> but can also use accelerated window managers like Compiz or [[KWin]].
Unity 2D is a set of individual applications.<ref name="2D-Components">[[:File:Unity-2D Natty.png]]</ref> They are written in the GUI building language QML from the widespread Qt framework.<ref name="2D-QML" /> By default Unity 2D uses the non-compositing [[Metacity]] window manager<ref name="2D-Components" /> but can also use accelerated window managers like Compiz or [[KWin]].
